questions.text: A 40 y/o male presents with a history of urinary incontinence and recurrent urinary tract infections. Imaging reveals a bladder with a thickened, trabeculated wall and an elongated shape, resembling a cone. Which of the following bladder appearances is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Christmas tree bladder

 

Explanation:

 

Bladder Appearances in Radiology

 

Christmas Tree bladder

(Option A)

Teardrop bladder

(Option D ruled out)

• Also known as the fir-tree bladder, it is typically seen in the neurogenic bladder due to detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia.

• The bladder appears elongated and trabeculated, resembling a pine cone or Christmas tree.

• Often associated with suprasacral lesions or epiconal lesions (above or around S2-S4). 

 

• Refers to a pear-shaped bladder caused by external compression. 

• It can result from pelvic hematoma, pelvic lipomatosis, or excess pelvic fat.

• The bladder may appear inverted or upright, depending on the source of compression.

Fetal Skull Calcification

(Option C ruled out)

Keyhole Appearance

(Option B ruled out)

• Occurs in advanced schistosomiasis.

• The bladder wall calcifies in a ringlike pattern, resembling a fetal skull on radiologic images.

• Common in cases of urogenital schistosomiasis, often with calcification of the ureters as well.

 

• Seen in patients with posterior urethral valves.

• It is the dilation of the proximal urethra and the presence of a distended, thick-walled bladder. 

• The ultrasound appearance resembles a keyhole.

questions.text: A 55 y/o woman undergoing routine health screening is found to have an incidental adrenal mass on ultrasound. The lesion is smooth, round, hypoechoic, and measures 2.5 cm with low vascularity. A non-contrast CT scan shows a density of 8 HU. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Adrenal adenoma

 

Explanation:

A smooth, round, hypoechoic lesion with low vascularity and a size of 2.5 cm is typical of a benign adrenal adenoma. The hallmark is a non-contrast CT density of 8 HU, indicating low attenuation (<10 HU), distinguishing it from other adrenal lesions.

 

Adrenal Adenoma

(Option C)

Pheochromocytoma

(Option A ruled out)

Adrenal Calcification

(Option B ruled out)

Common benign tumour, often hormonally inactive and less than 3 cm.

 

Ultrasound: Smooth, round, hypoechoic, and low vascularity.

CT: 

• Non-contrast shows a low density (<10 HU) if lipid-rich, and 10–30 HU if lipid-poor.

• Rapid enhancement with >60% washout on contrast-enhanced CT.

MRI: Signal drop on T1 out-of-phase imaging due to intralesional lipid.

Rare adrenal medulla tumour that secretes catecholamines.

 

CT: Heterogeneous and strongly enhancing.

MRI:

• T2 is hyperintense with a "light bulb" appearance.

• No signal loss on out-of-phase imaging.

• Fluid–fluid levels may indicate haemorrhage.

MIBG: Localizes tumour via increased adrenal uptake.

May result from old haemorrhage, infection, or various diseases (e.g., tuberculosis, neuroblastoma).

 

Plain X-ray: Calcifications may be diffuse, stippled, or arc-like depending on the cause.

 

CT:

• Early tuberculosis: Enlarged adrenal with peripheral enhancement.

• Advanced tuberculosis: Atrophic adrenals with scattered calcifications.

 

 

 

 

Metastasis (Option D): Metastatic lesions generally demonstrate higher attenuation values on non-contrast CT due to their lipid-poor nature. They often appear as irregular masses, which contrasts with the smooth and well-defined appearance of the lesion described here.

questions.text: A 65 y/o male with a history of coronary artery disease presents with hypertension resistant to medication. A Doppler ultrasound shows a renal artery to proximal aorta ratio (RAR) of 4:1 and a peak systolic velocity (PSV) of 250 cm/s. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Renal artery stenosis

 

Explanation: 

Renal artery stenosis is the most common cause of secondary hypertension. The Doppler ultrasound findings strongly support this diagnosis as well. 

 

Renal Artery Stenosis

(Option D)

Fibromuscular Dysplasia

(Option B ruled out)

• Narrowing of the arteries that supply blood to the kidneys.

• Common Causes:

  • Atherosclerosis (most common, especially in elderly patients).
  • Fibromuscular Dysplasia (FMD) (second most common, more frequent in young females).

• The second most common cause of RAS after atherosclerosis.

• Typically affects middle to distal renal arteries. More common in young females and often affects both kidneys.

Doppler Ultrasound Signs of RAS:

Direct signs:

• PSV > 180 cm/s.

• Renal artery to proximal aorta ratio (RAR) > 3.5:1.

• Aliasing artefacts and lack of Doppler signals.

Indirect signs:

Acceleration time > 70 ms. (Time from the start of systole to peak systole)

Turbulent flow with spectral broadening and increased resistive index.

"String of beads" pattern, showing alternating narrowings and dilatations.

CT Angiography (CTA) and MR Angiography (MRA): Provide detailed anatomical views of renal arteries and surrounding structures.

 

 

Ureteral obstruction (Option A): It impacts the urinary system and does not directly affect the blood flow in the renal arteries. It would not result in the arterial Doppler findings of elevated PSV and RAR.

 

Renal vein thrombosis (Option C): Renal vein thrombosis involves the veins rather than the arteries and would not produce the Doppler findings of elevated PSV or an increased RAR. It usually presents with other signs, such as hematuria or flank pain.

questions.text: A 45 y/o patient with a history of diabetes and prolonged analgesic use presents with signs of acute renal failure. A CT urography shows deformed calyces and filling defects in the pelvicalyceal system. What is the likely cause of the filling defects seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Necrosed papilla

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical features and radiographic findings point to Renal papillary necrosis. Renal papillary necrosis occurs due to ischemic damage, leading to the necrosis of the papilla. It is commonly seen in patients with diabetes mellitus.
  • These necrosed papillae can detach from the renal medulla and slough into the pelvicalyceal system, resulting in filling defects in CT urography. The sloughed papilla may also obstruct the ureter or vesicoureteric junction, contributing to acute renal failure and other complications. 

 

CT showing left-sided calyx clubbing and right-sided filling defects.

 

IVU Findings of Renal papillary necrosis:

 

  

claw appearance" data-author="" data-hash="7951" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="600" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/Obi4NMJwdfmNgdSBAhFS1744032652.png" width="600" />

Lobster claw appearance                

Renal papillary necrosis" data-author="" data-hash="7952" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="600" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/azOv7bMdAG4YzJWm62QF1744032666.png" width="600" />

A- Central erosion, B-Ball on the tee, C- Lobster claw, D- Signet ring, E- Calyceal blunting

 

Medullary sponge kidney (Option B): It involves cystic dilation of the renal collecting ducts and typically presents with linear striations or sponge-like appearances on imaging, which resolve with the use of contrast. It does not cause sloughing of the papilla or filling defects in the pelvicalyceal system like renal papillary necrosis. 

 

Ureteral stricture (Option C): A ureteral stricture causes narrowing of the ureter and may lead to obstruction of urine flow, but it does not cause filling defects within the calyces.  

 

Vesicoureteric reflux (Option D): This involves the abnormal backward flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters. However, VUR does not result in the sloughing of papillae or filling defects in the renal pelvicalyceal system, which are key features of renal papillary necrosis.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old infant is evaluated for an abdominal mass found during a routine examination. An ultrasound reveals large cysts in the kidney and it appears predominantly cystic with little to no identifiable renal parenchyma. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Multicystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK)

Explanation:

The ultrasound findings of a predominantly cystic kidney structure with large cysts, minimal renal parenchyma and the patient’s age align perfectly with MCDK, which typically presents with multiple cystic spaces replacing the kidney.

 

Multicystic dysplastic kidney:

  • Multicystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK) is a severe form of congenital kidney abnormality where the kidney is mostly made up of cysts and non-functioning, abnormally developed tissue.
  • Renal parenchyma is hardly seen.
  • Multiple cystic spaces replace the entire kidney.
  • Multicystic dysplastic kidney is usually unilateral.

 

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD):

  • It is a hereditary condition seen in infants.
  • There is dilatation of renal tubules.
  • Several tiny cysts (<2mm) are seen scattered throughout the renal parenchyma giving the kidney a striated appearance. (Option A ruled out)
  • X-ray: Bilateral flank masses due to nephromegaly (enlarged kidneys).
  • USG: Kidneys are predominantly hyperechoic with loss of corticomedullary differentiation. 
  • CT imaging: Shows smooth, enlarged kidneys with a striated pattern of contrast excretion. The striated pattern signifies the collection of contrast in dilated renal tubules.

 

Plain abdominal radiograph showing B/L flank mass

USG showing ARPKD

Striated nephrogram on CT

 

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) (Option C) generally presents in older children and adults and is characterized by larger cysts along with preserved renal parenchyma, not predominantly cystic kidneys in infancy.

 

Simple renal cysts (Option D) would not explain the significant loss of renal architecture seen in this infant's ultrasound and are generally not seen to replace the entire kidney.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman, with a family history of renal disease, presents with hematuria and hypertension. She has a history of recurrent flank pain and is currently diagnosed with renal failure. Ultrasound imaging is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)

Explanation:

The patient’s age, presenting history, family history, diagnosis of renal failure and ultrasound findings of multiple cysts align with the diagnosis of ADPKD, which is characterized by numerous renal cysts.

 

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

  • Familial disorder with autosomal dominant inheritance, classified as a ciliopathy.
  • Kidneys are progressively replaced by multiple cysts in the cortex and medulla, with initial preservation of intervening parenchyma.
  • ADPKD is typically diagnosed between ages 30 and 50, when symptoms first appear, thus being named "adult PKD”.
  • Typically presents in adults with hematuria, hypertension, and renal failure.
  • It is associated with other conditions namely intracranial aneurysms, heart valve dysfunctions, colonic diverticula, aortic dissection and cystic lesions in other organs like the liver, spleen and pancreas.

Imaging

 

Plain Radiograph

• Enlarged, multilobulated renal outlines with bowel displacement.

• Multiple calcifications, sometimes with multiple ring appearance.

• Intravenous urography: "Swiss cheese nephrogram" (due to multiple renal cysts), "Spiderleg pyelogram" (stretched pelvicalyceal system).

Ultrasound

• Simple cysts: Anechoic with thin walls, posterior acoustic enhancement, and lateral shadowing.

• Complicated cysts (haemorrhage/infection): Echogenic material within the cyst, possible wall calcification, absence of internal blood flow.

• CEUS: Demonstrates enhancement

CT

• Simple cysts: Rounded with near-water attenuation and thin walls.

• Complications (haemorrhage/infection): Higher attenuation and wall calcification.

MRI

• T2 MRI- The most sensitive imaging modality

• Both enlarged kidneys have multiple cysts

 

Simple renal cysts (Option A): While simple cysts appear anechoic with thin walls, the presence of multiple cysts in a familial context strongly suggests ADPKD.

 

Multicystic dysplastic kidney (Option C): This condition typically presents in children and is characterized by a non-functioning kidney with multiple cysts and intervening dysplastic tissue, which does not match this case.

 

Renal cell carcinoma (Option D) usually presents as a solid mass with possible necrosis or irregular borders, rather than multiple simple cysts.

questions.text: A 45 y/o woman presents with a family history of renal cell carcinoma, along with multiple skin lesions resembling fibrofolliculomas. She also reports episodes of spontaneous pneumothorax. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome

Explanation:
The presence of fibrofolliculomas, renal cell carcinoma, lung cysts, and spontaneous pneumothorax is characteristic of Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome, an autosomal dominant disorder.

Birt Hogg Dube syndrome

 

  • Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome (BHDS) is an autosomal dominant disorder clinically manifested by fibrofolliculomas, renal cell carcinoma, lung cysts, and spontaneous pneumothorax.
  • Caused by mutations in the FLCN gene, affecting folliculin, which is involved in cellular signaling and regulation.
  • The syndrome is rare and often presents in adults.
  • Patients have a higher likelihood of developing renal tumours, particularly chromophobe and oncocytoma types.

 

Fibrofolliculomas:

Papulous skin lesions

Renal Cell Carcinoma

CT showing hypodense lesions in the kidney.

Lung cysts on pulmonary CT

 

Angiomyolipoma

 

  • Angiomyolipoma consists of abnormal blood vessels, smooth muscle, and fat.
  • The risk of spontaneous retroperitoneal haemorrhage increases with larger lesions (>4cm) (Wunderlich syndrome).
  • Multiple angiomyolipomas suggest an association with tuberous sclerosis.
  • USG: Appears as hyperechoic on ultrasound.
  • CT:  CT scan shows fatty masses in the kidney. The presence of fat helps to distinguish it from other renal masses.

 

Angiomyolipoma (Option A) is a benign renal tumour associated with tuberous sclerosis but does not typically present with skin lesions like fibrofolliculomas or spontaneous pneumothorax.

 

Oncocytoma (Option B) is a benign renal tumour characterized by large eosinophilic cells but is not associated with fibrofolliculomas or lung cysts as seen in Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome. Moreover, oncocytoma presents with a central stellate scar in the kidney - visible on CT and MRI, which is not seen in this case.

Tuberous sclerosis (Option D) is associated with multiple hamartomas, including angiomyolipomas in the kidneys, but does not typically feature fibrofolliculomas or spontaneous pneumothorax as prominent findings.

questions.text: A 62 y/o female patient presents with hematuria and flank pain. A CECT scan reveals a solid hyper-enhancing renal mass measuring 5 cm. The radiologist notes heterogeneous enhancement and suggests further evaluation for possible extension into the inferior vena cava (IVC). Which of the following imaging modalities is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for potential IVC extension or thrombus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Contrast MRI

Explanation:

  • The patient likely has renal cell carcinoma, given the presence of a hyper-enhancing solid renal mass with heterogeneous enhancement on CECT, which is characteristic of this malignancy.
  • Contrast MRI is the most appropriate next step as it is the investigation of choice for detecting inferior vena cava extension or thrombus in renal cell carcinoma.

 

Renal cell carcinoma

CECT scan shows a right kidney mass suggestive of primary RCC

CT scan showing Renal cell carcinoma

 

  • Solid enhancing lesion.
  • Clear cell carcinoma is the most common type, comprising 85% of malignant renal tumours.
  • It is hyper-enhancing after contrast administration.
  • Associated with Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome, often with multiple small tumours in cysts.
  • Heterogeneous enhancement on CECT suggests renal cell carcinoma.
  • Renal cell carcinoma can extend into the inferior vena cava (IVC).
  • Contrast MRI is the investigation of choice to detect IVC extension or thrombus.
  • MRI helps differentiate benign vs. malignant thrombus by showing contrast uptake.
  • Contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice for renal cell carcinoma diagnosis and staging.
  • MRI is used in problem-solving or when contrast agents are contraindicated.

 

Contrast-enhanced ultrasound (Option A): While useful in certain contexts, it is less definitive for assessing vascular involvement compared to MRI.

 

Contrast-enhanced CT (Option B): Although it is the preferred modality for diagnosing and staging renal cell carcinoma, the scenario specifically calls for evaluation of IVC extension, which is better assessed with MRI.

 

Plain abdominal X-ray (Option D): This modality is not suitable for assessing the extent of renal cell carcinoma or IVC involvement.

questions.text:
A 45 y/o male undergoes an imaging study for evaluation of flank pain. A CECT scan reveals a renal cyst with multiple hairline thin septa and minimal wall thickening. The cyst shows thick nodular calcifications but no measurable enhancement after contrast administration. Based on the Bosniak classification, which of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient?

 



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: No follow-up is needed; continue routine monitoring.
Follow-up imaging every 6 months for 1 year.
Surgical excision or ablation of the cyst.
Follow-up imaging every 6 weeks for 1 year.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Follow-up imaging every 6 months for 1 year.

 

Explanation:

The CT findings describe a renal cyst with multiple hairline thin septa, minimal wall thickening, and thick nodular calcifications. These features are consistent with Category IIF of the Bosniak classification. The recommended management for this category includes close follow-up with imaging every 6 months for 1 year to monitor any changes.

 

Bosniak Classification of Renal Cysts & Management

Classification of Renal Cysts" data-author="" data-hash="7935" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="700" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/ixl4eW6dgICxsSOpG04v1744030694.png" width="700" />

 

Category

Description

Management

Category I

• Simple cyst, fluid density, hairline thin wall.

• No septa, calcifications, or solid components.

• No enhancement post-intravenous contrast.

CT showing a simple cyst.

• No follow-up is required.

Category II

• Cyst with some hairline thin septa, and fine calcifications.

• Uniformly high-density (<3 cm).

• No measurable enhancement.

CT showing hairline septa and fine calcifications

• No follow-up is required.

• US or CT may be sufficient for characterisation.

Category IIF

• Multiple hairline thin septa, minimal wall/septa thickening.

• Thick nodular calcifications or uniformly high-density (>3 cm).

• Malignancy Risk: ~20%

• Follow-up:

◦ Every 6 months for 1 year with CT or MRI.

◦ Followed by Imaging done annually for at least the next 5 years.

◦ May progress to Category III or IV.

Category III

• Thickened, irregular, or smooth enhancing walls/septa.

• Malignancy Risk: ~50%

CT showing thickened septa

• Treatment: Surgical excision/ablation due to high malignancy risk.

• Imaging:

◦ Contrast-enhanced triphasic CT for follow-up.

Category IV

• Same as Category III with additional soft-tissue components independent of walls/septa.

• Malignancy Risk: ~90%

CT showing thickened septa with additional soft tissue components

• Treatment: Surgical excision/ablation is recommended.

• Imaging: Same protocol as Category III for imaging with triphasic CT.

 

No follow-up needed; continue routine monitoring (Option A): Inappropriate because follow-up is needed due to the presence of septa and calcifications.

 

Surgical excision or ablation of the cyst (Option C): Surgical excision is not typically indicated for Category IIF cysts given the lower risk of malignancy.

 

Follow-up imaging every 6 weeks for 1 year(Option D): This is an excessively frequent follow-up schedule, making it an unrealistic and incorrect option.

questions.text:
A 2 y/o child presents with abdominal distension and a palpable abdominal mass. A CT scan is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neuroblastoma

Explanation:

Neuroblastoma commonly occurs in children under 2 years, presents as a poorly marginated mass encasing vascular structures, and is associated with features such as midline crossing, which aligns with the CT findings. CT shows a hypodense mass displacing the kidney posteriorly and displacing structures away from the midline.

 

Wilms Tumor (Nephroblastoma)

Neuroblastoma

• Calcification: Uncommon (10-15%)

• Vascular involvement: Displaces renal vessels but does not encase them

• Age group: Slightly older (peak at 3-4 years)

• Margins: Well-circumscribed

• Claw sign: Kidney claw sign present

• Vascular extension: Common into IVC/renal vein

• Midline crossing: Does not cross midline

• Bone metastases: Rare, lung metastases are common

• Spinal canal extension: Never seen

• Retroperitoneal lymph nodes: Uncommon

• Hemorrhage: Higher incidence

 

• Calcification: Very common

• Vascular involvement: Encases but does not invade vessels

• Age group: Younger (<2 years)

• Margins: Poorly marginated

• Aorta: Elevates aorta away from the vertebral column

• Midline crossing: Frequently crosses the midline, especially behind the aorta

• Thoracic extension: Common

• Bone metastases: Common (Hutchinson syndrome)

• Spinal canal extension: Can occur

• Retroperitoneal lymph nodes: Common

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Wilms Tumor (Nephroblastoma) (Option A): Typically presents in slightly older children (peak at 3-4 years) with well-circumscribed margins, making this less likely.

Renal Cell Carcinoma (Option C): More common in adults and does not typically present in this age group.

Hepatoblastoma (Option D): While it can present in young children, it typically originates from the liver rather than the kidneys and does not match the imaging findings described.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe pelvic pain after a motor vehicle collision. CT cystogram of the patient is given below. What type of injury is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Extraperitoneal bladder rupture

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario, history and CT findings of pelvic molar tooth sign due to contrast leakage into the preperitoneal space suggest the diagnosis of Extraperitoneal bladder rupture associated with pelvic fractures.

 

1. Urethral rupture 

 

 

 

  • Contrast flows out of the urethra.
  • In pelvic fracture, membranous urethra rupture occurs.
  • In straddle injury, bulbous urethra rupture occurs.

 

2. Bladder rupture

  • Can be of 2 types

 

Extra Peritoneal bladder rupture

Intra Peritoneal bladder rupture

• Caused by pelvic fractures and rapid deceleration.

• Leakage into thighs, perineum, penis, anterior abdominal wall.

• Commonly associated with pelvic fractures.

• The pelvic molar tooth sign refers to contrast media leaking from the bladder and accumulating in the preperitoneal space, creating a molar tooth-shaped appearance on CT cystography after extraperitoneal bladder rupture.

• Occurs at the bladder dome, above the peritoneal reflection.

• Caused by a direct blow to a distended bladder.

• Urine leakage into the abdomen; causes metabolic derangements.

 

 

 

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture (Option A): Less likely, as this type typically does not present with the molar tooth sign or urethral contrast extravasation.

 

Bulbous urethra rupture (Option C): Unlikely, as the scenario primarily indicates bladder involvement rather than a specific urethral injury.

 

Membranous urethra rupture (Option D): Less likely, as the symptoms and imaging findings suggest a bladder injury rather than an isolated urethral rupture.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with difficulty urinating and a history of profuse, creamy urethral discharge. He reports a prior untreated sexually transmitted infection. The urethrogram of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bulbar urethral stricture

 

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of difficulty urinating and a history of profuse, creamy urethral discharge strongly suggest a gonococcal infection, which can lead to inflammation and scarring in the bulbar urethra, resulting in a stricture. The urethrogram findings of narrowing specifically in the bulbar urethra support this diagnosis.

 

Parts of urethra

 

Bulbar urethral stricture

• Stricture seen in the bulbar urethra.

• Common in gonorrhoea.

• Presents with profuse, purulent or mucopurulent urethral discharge.

Stricture of distal penile urethra

• Urethrogram showing narrowing in the distal urethra.

 

Urethral carcinoma (Option A): Less likely due to the absence of risk factors and the typical presentation of malignancy, which would not match the history of an untreated STI.

 

Penile urethral stricture (Option C): Unlikely, as the urethrogram shows narrowing in the bulbar urethra, and penile strictures are less common in this context.

 

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) (Option D): Unlikely due to the patient's younger age and specific symptoms that align more with a urethral stricture rather than bladder outlet obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the indications for Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG) and Retrograde Urethrography (RUG)?

choices.text: VCUG is the gold standard for evaluating urethral strictures.
RUG is the gold standard for detecting vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
VCUG is the most important modality for examining urinary tract anomalies in children.
Blood at the urethral meatus is a key indicator for performing VCUG.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) VCUG is the most important modality for examining urinary tract anomalies in children.

 

Explanation:

VCUG is indeed the most important modality for urological examination in children, particularly for evaluating VUR and related urinary tract anomalies.

 

Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG)/ Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCUG)

Retrograde Urethrography (RUG)

• VCUG is a fluoroscopic procedure used to assess the anatomy and function of the bladder and urethra, primarily to detect vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). (Option B ruled out)

• The most important modality for urological examination in children.

• MCUG is the gold standard for evaluating VUR.

• VUR is the retrograde passage of urine from the bladder into the ureter and potentially the calyces.

• A diagnostic procedure used to accurately diagnose, stage, and delineate urethral strictures.

• The gold standard in the management of urethral stricture disease. (Option A ruled out)

• Can be combined with voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) for better visualization of complex cases.

• Contrast media is injected retrogradely into the urethra, followed by a series of radiographs.

Indications:

• Anomalies of the urinary tract: (Option C)

◦ Anorectal malformation.

◦ Myelodysplasia.

◦ Prune-belly syndrome.

• Febrile urinary tract infection (particularly if recurrent).

• Hydronephrosis or hydroureter.

• Hematuria.

• Voiding abnormalities:

◦ Dysuria.

◦ Dysfunctional voiding (neurogenic bladder).

◦ Incontinence.

• Neonatal ascites.

• Trauma.

• Postoperative evaluation of the urinary tract.

Indications:

• Pelvic trauma with suspicion of urethral injury.

• Urethral obstruction.

• Foreign bodies in the urethra.

• Urethral diverticula.

• Suspected urethral fistula.

• Blood at the urethral meatus is a key indicator for testing. (Option D ruled out)

• Catheter placement should be withheld until RUG to prevent worsening injury.

• Evaluation for rectal trauma and checking for a high-riding prostate is essential.

questions.text:
A 45 y/o male presents with right-sided flank pain and recurrent urinary tract infections. The imaging study is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Retro-caval ureter

 

Explanation:

Imaging shows a medial deviation of the right ureter. A retro-caval ureter is caused by a developmental anomaly in which the ureter is trapped behind the IVC due to improper embryological development of the vena cava. This leads to a characteristic medial deviation of the ureter at the L3-L4 level. Patients with this condition often present with flank pain, recurrent urinary tract infections, and hydronephrosis due to impaired urine flow through the kinked or obstructed ureter. 

 

 

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (Option A): This condition occurs when urine flows backwards from the bladder into the ureters, leading to recurrent urinary infections and kidney damage. While it can result in hydronephrosis and recurrent infections, it is not associated with medial deviation of the ureter.

 

Transitional cell carcinoma (Option B): This type of cancer affects the lining of the urinary tract, most commonly the bladder and ureters. It can cause symptoms like hematuria and flank pain, but it is not associated with the specific imaging feature of medial deviation of the ureter. Instead, transitional cell carcinoma typically presents with filling defects and dilatation of the ureter above the tumour giving a, known as the "goblet sign," and does not lead to the ureter passing behind the IVC. 

 

 

Polycystic kidney disease (Option C): This genetic disorder is characterised by the growth of numerous fluid-filled cysts in the kidneys, leading to enlarged kidneys and impaired function and is not linked to ureter deviation or hydronephrosis.

questions.text:
A 35 y/o female presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and mild flank pain. An ultrasound reveals a cystic dilation near the lower ureter, and an IVU is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Ureterocele

 

Explanation:

The given IVU shows- a smooth, rounded structure with a radiolucent halo at the ureterovesical junction, also known as the "cobra head" appearance, which is a hallmark of a ureterocele. It results from cystic dilation of the distal ureter, which can cause recurrent infections, as seen in this case.

 

  • A ureterocele is a congenital dilation of the terminal part of the ureter where it enters the bladder. It consists of layers of ureteric and bladder epithelium.
  • Cobraneck appearance on IVU is a hallmark feature where a dilated contrast-filled ureter is surrounded by a thin rim of the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa, typically measuring less than 2 mm in diameter.

 

Ureterocele

 

 

 

 

Note: 

  • Maiden waist deformity is a term given to describe the medial deviation of both ureters. 
  • Commonly seen in retroperitoneal fibrosis or unilateral cases of retrocaval ureter.
  • The ureters take a narrow, waist-like shape, resembling the waist of a maiden, usually at the level of the lumbosacral junction.

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (Option B): While reflux can lead to recurrent UTIs, it does not present with the cobra head appearance described on imaging. 

 

Hydronephrosis (Option C): This condition results from obstruction, leading to dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces. However, it does not produce the specific cobra head appearance at the ureterovesical junction.

 

Renal calculi (Option D): While stones can cause flank pain and UTIs, they appear as radiopaque densities on imaging and do not have the cobra head sign seen with a ureterocele.

questions.text: Which of the following is a typical finding in the end-stage tuberculosis of the kidney, visible on abdominal radiography?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Putty kidney

 

Explanation:

 

Tuberculosis of the urinary tract

Kidneys

Renal Pelvis and Calyces

Ureters

Bladder

Calcifications: Lobar pattern and putty kidney in advanced cases.

Infundibular Strictures: Phantom calyces due to obstruction in early disease.

(Option B ruled out)

Granulomas and Abscesses: Seen as hypodense areas on CT, hypoechoic on ultrasound, or hypointense on MRI.

Calyceal Deformities: Irregular, distorted, or enlarged calyces due to strictures.

Cavities: Formed by erosion and scarring.

Hydrocalycosis: Detected on IVU and USG as calyceal dilation.

Strictures and Stenosis: Leading to a sawtooth or beaded appearance on IVU.

(Option C ruled out)

Hydroureter: Indicated by uneven ureteral dilation due to obstruction.

Thimble Bladder: Bladder contraction from fibrosis, evident on MRI.

Bladder Wall Thickening: Seen with trabeculation and ureterovesical junction involvement, causing reflux.


 

 

 

 

 

Hydronephrosis (Option D): This describes the dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces due to obstruction of urine flow, which can occur in many conditions, including tuberculosis. In end-stage renal tuberculosis, calcification (putty kidney) is a more prominent feature than hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A 45 y/o woman with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections presents with fever, flank pain, and weight loss. An ultrasound reveals an enlarged kidney with a large echogenic centre, and CT confirms the presence of a staghorn calculus along with renal enlargement and calyceal dilatation. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis

Explanation:

Acute Pyelonephritis

(Option A ruled out)

Xanthogranulomatous Pyelonephritis

(Option B)

Emphysematous Pyelonephritis

(Option C ruled out)

Ultrasound (USG): This may show kidney enlargement, reduced echogenicity, and dilated collecting systems.

 

 

 

Ultrasound (USG): Shows an enlarged kidney with echogenic staghorn calculi and hypoechoic masses replacing renal parenchyma.

 

 

Plain Abdominal X-ray: Detects gas in the kidney region in about 70% of cases.  

 

Contrast-enhanced CT: Most sensitive, showing wedge-shaped hypodense areas, striated nephrograms, and pelvic wall thickening.

 

CT Scan reveals a non-functioning kidney, staghorn calculus, expanded calyces, and inflammatory changes. A characteristic bear paw sign is noted.

CT: Gold standard, reveals gas within the kidney, renal enlargement, perinephric stranding and abscesses. Helps classify into Type 1 (gas without fluid) or Type 2 (gas with fluid). 

 

Acute infection of the kidney involving the renal parenchyma and collecting system is usually caused by ascending bacteria.

• It is a chronic granulomatous response to recurrent renal infection - that leads to the destruction of renal parenchyma and its replacement by lipid-laden foamy macrophages.

• Destruction spreads from the renal pelvis→medulla→ cortex. 

• Usually, staghorn calculus is present in the pelvis.

Severe necrotizing infection with gas accumulation in and around the kidney, primarily in diabetic patients.

 

Acute lobar nephronia (Option D): It is a localized form of acute pyelonephritis that affects one or more kidney lobes. It presents with mass-like lesions and poor perfusion in the affected area but is not associated with staghorn calculi or such widespread renal changes as seen in this case.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a history of antenatal hydronephrosis detected on prenatal ultrasound. He now reports recurrent urinary tract infections and intermittent flank pain. Diuretic renography reveals delayed drainage of radiotracer. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ureteropelvic junction (PUJ) obstruction

 

Explanation:

Ureteropelvic junction (PUJ) obstruction is the most likely diagnosis, as it is characterised by delayed radiotracer washout on diuretic renography, indicating obstruction at the junction where the ureter meets the renal pelvis. Antenatal hydronephrosis is also a common presentation of PUJ obstruction.

 

Feature

PUJ Obstruction

Vesicoureteric (VUR)

Staghorn Calculus

Location

Narrowing at the junction of the renal pelvis and ureter.

Retrograde urine flows from the bladder into the ureters.

Large, branched stone within the renal pelvis and calyces

Cause

Commonly: Congenital defect in ureteral muscle development.

Less commonly: Compression by an aberrant or accessory renal artery branch.

Malformation of the distal ureter, leading to an inadequate valve mechanism at the vesicoureteric junction

Urinary tract infection with urease-producing bacteria in the setting of alkaline urine and elevated ammonia levels.

Presentation

Neonates: Antenatally detected hydronephrosis.

Older children/Adults: Palpable mass, intermittent flank/abdominal pain

Antenatal hydronephrosis, recurrent urinary tract infections

Symptoms of urinary tract infection (e.g., pain, fever, frequent urination), flank pain, haematuria

Imaging

Ultrasound: Visualisation of hydronephrosis.

Diuretic renography: Delayed radiotracer washout indicating obstruction

Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG): Demonstrates retrograde urine flow from the bladder into the ureters.

DMSA scan: Can detect renal scarring, a potential complication of VUR.

CT scan: Depicts the large, branched stone; can assess for hydronephrosis and other complications. Plain radiograph: May also visualise the stone.

 

 

Staghorn calculus (Option A) typically causes flank pain and hematuria but would not explain the antenatal hydronephrosis or delayed washout.

 

Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) (Option B) might cause recurrent UTIs but does not present with flank and abdominal pain. It also has a prompt washout of the radiotracer as it is a reflux disorder and not a blockage.

 

Urinary tract infection (Option D) may explain some symptoms but does not account for the delayed washout seen in the imaging studies, nor does it explain the antenatal hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A 66 y/o woman presents with pelvic pain and a palpable mass. Imaging studies show a pelvic mass with extensive calcification that has a characteristic "popcorn" appearance. Which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Severe uterine leiomyoma (fibroid)

 

Explanation:

Severe uterine leiomyoma (fibroid) is associated with popcorn calcification, which appears as irregular, scattered calcifications in imaging studies, particularly in postmenopausal women. 

Urinary Tract Calculi

 

 

 

 

Type of Calculi

Description

Characteristics

Imaging Findings

 

Ureteric Calculi

(Option A ruled out)

These are stones located in the ureters, which carry urine from the kidneys to the bladder.

Size impacts the likelihood of spontaneous passage:

• <5 mm: High chance of passing naturally.

• >10 mm: Less likely to pass without intervention.

• Identified via CT urography.

• Can lead to hydronephrosis if it obstructs urine flow. 

• White areas in the KUB X-ray indicate calcifications observed in the paravertebral location.

 

Vesical Calculi

(Option B ruled out)

Stones that are found in the bladder.

Stones can either get impacted at the vesicoureteric junction or be mobile in the bladder.

• CT urography is valuable for differentiation between the two.

• Prone positioning during imaging aids in differentiation. 

• Usually appears as a dense calcification in the centre of the pelvis.

 

Popcorn Calcification

A radiological finding associated with severely calcified uterine fibroids (leiomyomas).

• Irregular, scattered calcifications resembling popped corn.

• Common in postmenopausal women with degenerative changes in fibroids.

• On X-ray: Pelvic mass with severe calcification, characteristic popcorn pattern.

• On CT: clearer visualisation confirming calcified leiomyoma.

 

 

Ovarian teratoma (Option D) may also present with calcifications but typically does not exhibit the distinct popcorn pattern seen in severely calcified leiomyomas.

questions.text:
A 60 y/o male presents with chronic back pain and a history of tuberculosis. A CT scan of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Putty kidney

 

Explanation:

The CT shows a calcified mass of the left kidney, often referred to as "putty-like," indicating dystrophic calcification. Putty kidney is seen in advanced renal tuberculosis, where extensive calcification and atrophy lead to a non-functioning kidney.

 

Calcifications in the Kidney:

Description

Staghorn Calculus

Putty Kidney

Medullary Nephrocalcinosis

Description

Large, branching stone filling the renal pelvis and calyces, resembling the shape of a staghorn.

Tissue damage in the kidney by TB leads to dystrophic calcification. Indicates end-stage renal TB.

Calcium deposition within the renal medulla (inner kidney).

Cause

Struvite stones formed from magnesium ammonium phosphate due to infection with urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Klebsiella, Proteus)

Renal tuberculosis leads to granuloma formation causing necrosis, cavitation, fibrosis and stricture formation.

Metabolic disturbances (e.g., hyperparathyroidism, sarcoidosis, renal tubular acidosis, medullary sponge kidney disease) leading to calcification of the renal medulla

Imaging Characteristics

Radio-opaque, visible on CT. They often form rapidly; fill the renal pelvis and extend into calyces. (Option A ruled out)

Appears as a lobulated mass of calcified tissue on CT scans, resembling "putty"; indicating a non-functioning kidney.

Detected on plain radiographs, ultrasound, and CT. USG and CT are very specific and hence useful even in mild cases

  • USG- hyperechoic renal parenchyma with posterior acoustic shadowing.
 
  • CT- High-density renal parenchyma in the medulla(Option B ruled out)

 

Renal cell carcinoma (Option D) can present with a mass, but calcification is less common, and the presentation would typically involve a solid tumour mass rather than complete calcification and atrophy of the kidney.

questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents with sudden onset of severe right-sided flank pain and gross hematuria. He has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. A non-contrast CT scan reveals a large, radio-opaque stone forming a staghorn shape in the renal pelvis. Which of the following is the most likely composition of the stone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Struvite

 

Explanation:

Struvite stones are associated with recurrent urinary tract infections and are radio-opaque, often forming staghorn calculi in the renal pelvis. The bacteria that contribute to this include Proteus and Klebsiella. 

 

 

 

Urolithiasis: 

  • Definition: Formation of urinary tract stones.
  • Presentation: Flank pain, hematuria (blood in urine).
  • Cause: Crystal formation due to the build-up of substances that should typically dissolve in urine.

Types of Stones and Imaging Visibility:

 

Type of Stone

Composition

Cause/Associated Condition

Imaging Visibility

Calcium-based stones

Calcium oxalate or calcium phosphate

(Option B ruled out)

High levels of calcium or oxalate in urine

Radio-opaque (easily detected on imaging)

Struvite stones

Magnesium ammonium phosphate

Urinary tract infections (Klebsiella, Proteus, etc.)

Radio-opaque (can form large staghorn calculi)

Uric acid stones

Uric acid (Option A ruled out)

Acidic urine, gout, obesity, diabetes

5-8% are radiolucent and can dissolve with urine alkalinisation

Cystine stones

Cystine (Option D ruled out)

Genetic disorder (cystinuria)

Some radiolucent; detectable via unenhanced CT

Drug-related stones

Drug crystals (e.g., Indinavir)

Certain medications (e.g., Indinavir)

Radiolucent (harder to detect)

Radiolucent stones: Uric acid, cystine, xanthine, ammonium urate, indinavir

 

Imaging Techniques for Urolithiasis:

  • Unenhanced CT: Preferred imaging modality. High sensitivity and ability to locate stones, measure size, and detect complications like hydronephrosis.

Dual-energy CT: Differentiates stone composition (e.g., uric acid vs. calcium stones), guiding treatment.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is evaluated for recurrent urinary tract infections. Imaging studies reveal that she has a duplex collecting system, with the upper renal moiety's ureter inserting ectopically into the bladder. The lower renal moiety's ureter is positioned normally. According to Weigert-Meyer law, which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

choices.text: The upper renal moiety's ureter typically drains into the bladder orthotopically.
The lower renal moiety's ureter is more likely to be associated with ureterocele.
Vesicoureteral reflux is more common with the lower renal moiety's ureter.
The ectopic ureter insertion of the upper moiety is often located lateral to the lower moiety's

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vesicoureteral reflux is more common with the lower renal moiety's ureter.

 

Explanation:

The diagnosis of a duplex collecting system is supported by the recurrent UTIs and imaging findings showing separate ureters, with the upper moiety's ureter likely inserting ectopically per Weigert-Meyer law, leading to potential complications like vesicoureteral reflux. 

The normal position of the lower renal moiety's ureter, as per Weigert-Meyer's law, is associated with a higher risk of vesicoureteral reflux.

 

Cross fused Ectopic

• A rare congenital malformation where both kidneys are located on one side of the body (unilaterally), with the ureter of the crossed kidney draining into the bladder on the opposite side (contralateral).

 

• Presentations can range from incidental findings during imaging to renal impairment, depending on the function and anatomy of the affected kidneys.

 

• Often identified through ultrasound, CT, or MRI, showing the kidneys positioned on the same side and their unique drainage patterns.

Duplex collecting system

• A common congenital renal tract abnormality is characterized by incomplete fusion of upper and lower pole moieties, leading to complete or incomplete duplication of the collecting system.

 

• Duplex collecting systems may be associated with vesicoureteric reflux, obstruction, or ureterocele, despite being considered anatomical variants.

 

• Imaging Characteristics: IVP can effectively image both collecting systems, but poorly functioning systems may not excrete contrast, resulting in a "drooping lily appearance" of the functioning lower pole moiety.

Weigert Meyer Law

• Ureteral Drainage: The upper and lower renal moieties each have separate ureters, each with its own orifice in the bladder. 

 

• Ectopic Insertion: The upper renal moiety ureter typically inserts ectopically, medial and inferior to the lower renal moiety ureter, often leading to a ureterocele. (Option D ruled out)

 

• Orthotopic Insertion: The lower renal moiety ureter inserts orthotopically, lateral and superior to the upper moiety's ureter, with a risk of vesicoureteral reflux. (Options A  & B ruled out)

questions.text:
A 30 y/o presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and abdominal discomfort. An abdominal ultrasound is performed, revealing a fusion anomaly of the kidneys. Further imaging confirms the presence of a unique kidney shape, where both upper and lower poles are merged and located anterior to the aortic bifurcation. The CT Abdomen of the patient is given below. Which of the following is not the most likely diagnosis of the patient?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Horseshoe Kidney

 

Explanation:

The patient's presentation—recurrent urinary tract infections and abdominal discomfort—along with the imaging findings suggest a renal fusion anomaly. The specific characteristics described point towards pancake kidney also known as discoid or fused pelvic kidney, where both the upper and lower poles of the kidneys are merged, creating a flat, disk-like appearance.

  • The Horseshoe kidney features fusion at the lower poles and does not present this specific morphology.

 

Horseshoe Kidney

Pancake Kidney

• The most common renal fusion anomaly occurs in approximately 1 in 1000 births.

• Results from abnormal migration and midline fusion of both kidneys, usually at the lower poles (90%).

• Kidneys point medially and are connected by a fibrous band or functioning renal parenchyma known as isthmus which is not divided.

• Normal renal ascent is halted by the inferior mesenteric artery origin. Usually present between 3rd to 5th Lumbar vertebrae.

• Imaging Characteristics:

◦ On plain film and IVU, a characteristic horseshoe configuration is observed, though the isthmus may be poorly visualized.

◦ Kidneys are typically low-lying and malrotated, with upper poles at the same height pointing superolateral, and lower poles pointing inferomedially.

• Complications such as pelvic ureteric junction obstruction (PUJO), calculi, and Wilms' tumour.

• Associated with gastrointestinal anomalies, cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS), and syndromes like Turner’s or Ellis–van Creveld.

• A rare renal fusion anomaly where the upper and lower poles of the kidneys merge, resembling a pancake.

• Typically located anterior to the aortic bifurcation.

• Usually has two separate ureters, but can occasionally have one.

• Other Names: Discoid kidney, fused pelvic kidney, cake kidney. (Option B, C & D ruled out)

• Often asymptomatic but can lead to:

◦ Ureteropelvic junction obstruction

◦ Recurrent infections

◦ Kidney stones

◦ Increased risk of malignancies

• Identified through ultrasound, CT, MRI, IVU, and scintigraphy.
